overview: From 2025-09-01 to 2025-10-01, ethereum-optimism/infra had 22 new PRs (19 merged), 8 new issues, and 74 active contributors.

topIssues.title: [sync-tester] Expose More Networks inside CI Box
topIssues.author: pcw109550
topIssues.body:
## Description

op-sync-tester unlocks testing the L2CL syncing with real chain data without actually writing to the L2 EL, but we need a real data source for this.

[The second milestone of sync-tester](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17253) requires validation of op-node with sync-tester for below networks inside the CI Box:
- `op-sepolia`, `base-sepolia`, `op-mainnet`, `base-mainnet`.

Currently the CI box can access below four endpoints:
- https://ci-sepolia-l1.optimism.io/ (L1 Sepolia EL endpoint) 
- https://ci-sepolia-beacon.optimism.io/ (L1 Sepolia beacon endpoint) 
- https://ci-sepolia-l2.optimism.io/ (L2 OP Sepolia EL endpoint) 
- https://ci-mainnet-l1.optimism.io/ (L1 Mainnet EL endpoint)

We have all required RPCs(see background section for reason) for testing `op-sepolia` at the moment, but we need more endpoints exposed inside the CI box for testing other networks.

Exhaustively listing the required requested endpoints inside the CI Box,

1. L1 Mainnet beacon endpoint
2. L2 OP Mainnet EL endpoint
3. L2 Base Mainnet EL endpoint
4. L2 Base Sepolia EL endpoint

## Background

op-sync-tester is a tool that mocks L2 EL. To test the L2 CL(especially the op-node) targeting the real chain, we needed some synced real L2 EL which is stateful. op-sync-tester mocks upon already synced L2 EL, and gives ease of testing the L2 CL implementation.

To mock, we need L2 EL endpoint, and to signal the L2 CL, we need L1 EL and L1 Beacon endpoint.

topIssues.title: Script Permissionless Devnet Spinup
topIssues.author: jelias2
topIssues.body:
# Description
Improve the [devnet spinup runbook](https://www.notion.so/oplabs/Devnet-Spinup-Runbook-17af153ee16280f3b610e808143cd02a?pvs=4) permissionless upgrade steps to be a runnable shell script, it should not be copy/paste shell commands. 

* Ideally the script should read from a an op-deployer intent or state to minimize human error

topIssues.title: [nat] Proofs smoke tests
topIssues.author: scharissis
topIssues.body:
Implement the requested [smoke tests](https://www.notion.so/oplabs/Proofs-Devnet-Acceptance-Testing-183f153ee162806f9dd6c4279967d946?pvs=4#183f153ee16280889096ec023bc7be8e) in order to support the Proofs team:

1. op-challenger running and operating nominally
2. op-dispute-mon running and operating nominally
3. op-proposer proposing valid outputs. Output validity is sanity checked by the op-challenger

topPRs.title: refactor(op-acceptor): test runner
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body:
Refactors the monolithic 1,755-line runner/runner.go file into 5 focused components to improve maintainability and separation of concerns:

  - TestExecutor: Individual test execution and process management
  - OutputParser: Go test JSON output parsing with timeout handling
  - ResultCollector: Hierarchical result aggregation (gates/suites/tests)
  - TestCoordinator: Test workflow orchestration
  - JSONStore: Raw JSON storage and retrieval

topPRs.title: feat(acceptance-tests): adds simple acceptance tests
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body:
Adds basic acceptance tests. These are used to test end-to-end integration with op-devstack.
Also adds a new make commands to run these.

topPRs.title: fix(op-acceptor): improved logging
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body:
Various logging fixes and improvements:
- Fix parser to capture subtest stdout output
- Handle plain text output when JSON parsing produces no content
- Ensure HTML report links match actual created files
- Add file existence checking in LogPathGenerator
- Strip ANSI escape sequences from plaintext output
- Added tests for all the above

topPRs.title: feat(op-acceptor): flake shake
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body: ## Description Introduces a new runner mode - "flake-shake", which runs tests many times to identify flaky ones. HTML and JSON reports are produced for CI artifacts. These will be used to aggregate results across multiple runners and , possibly, runs.

topPRs.title: op-acceptor: add console progress indicator
topPRs.author: bitwiseguy
topPRs.body:
# Overview
Users of `op-acceptor` would like more information to help debug tests that are stalled or taking longer than expected. Prior to this pr there was the framework for a `ProgressIndicator` to provide feedback to the user about testing progress, but only a no-op indicator was used. This pr adds a `ConsoleProgressIndicator`, which will print logs to the console while tests are running. Logs have this format:
```
INFO [09-11|14:12:31.263] progress update                          gate=gateless suite= completed=1 total=32 percent=3.1% numRunning=16 longestRunning="./tests/interop/message (5s), ./tests/interop/prep (5s), ./tests/interop/proofs (5s), +13 more"
```

# Details
Currently, the `ConsoleProgressIndicator` is disabled by default. To enable it, set the `ShowProgress = true` field on the `op-acceptor` config. There is also a new config field for `ProgressInterval` (how often to print a log/update), which defaults to 30s.

Only the 3 longest running tests are logged at any given time (to keep logging printout minimal while still providing the most useful information). As tests complete, they are removed from the data structures that are used to populate the progress logs.

# Tests
Added `progress_test.go` to test the new functionality by capturing logs and parsing them for expected output.

## Related Issues
* Closes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/issues/456

completedItems.title: fix(op-acceptor): go releaser
completedItems.body:
When mise is activated, it intercepts the go command through shims. If Go isn't installed via mise, the shim fails even if Go is available in the system.
We make this workaround here for just op-acceptor as only op-acceptor uses mise in th

- Updated our reproducible env and output reproducible-env.txt

topContributors.summary: geoknee: Focused on the "min-base-fee" feature, proposing changes to both implementation and design documentation. This work included opening a pull request to bring in op-geth code in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17307) and another to update a calculation in the feature's design doc (#333). Alongside this development, they actively supported the team by providing 12 code reviews. Their commits primarily consisted of bug fixes and tests, spread across 47 modified files.

scharissis: Focused on improving infrastructure and the acceptance testing framework, landing a significant logging refactor in `ethereum-optimism/infra#453` and introducing `mise` for tool version management via `ethereum-optimism/infra#452`. They drove further testing improvements by creating and closing two issues (`infra#398`, `optimism#16272`) to streamline test execution and provided 7 code reviews. With ongoing work in `op-acceptance-tests` and `kurtosis-devnet`, their contributions were primarily centered on bug fixes and feature enhancements.

blmalone: Focused on improving CI performance and stability within the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository. They delivered a notable performance improvement by optimizing account access decoding in CI (#1178) and reduced common CI failures by adjusting concurrent processes (#1177). Their work, primarily consisting of bug fixes, also included smaller corrections to versioning and nonce handling (#1183, #1176), with changes concentrated in documentation and configuration files.

smartcontracts: This month, smartcontracts focused on a significant body of work centered on bug fixes and new features, authoring 31 commits. This effort resulted in substantial changes across 167 files (+4676/-1739 lines), with a primary focus on bugfix work (68%). While no pull requests were merged, they participated in code review by providing comments on 4 pull requests.

JosepBove: Focused on the `superchain-ops` repository, preparing a significant change to enable and disable LivenessModule2 templates. This work is captured in an open pull request (#1179) which modifies 130 files with over 5,000 lines of code changes. Alongside this development effort, they also participated in code review by providing comments on 6 pull requests. Based on the file modifications, this work had a strong emphasis on testing.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on improving the project's build process, opening a pull request to enhance the build recipe for op-deployer (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17304). In addition to this work, they contributed collaboratively by reviewing and approving one pull request and commenting on an issue. Their code changes were entirely focused on this tooling enhancement.

pcw109550: This month, pcw109550 focused on improving the testing capabilities within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. Their main contribution was adding sync namespace support to the `op-sync-tester` via PR #17299. In addition to this merged work, they identified further testing needs by creating issues to address flakiness and add more tests (#17298, #17313), and also provided 3 code reviews. All of their code changes were concentrated in test files, reflecting a primary focus on test development and refactoring.

maurelian: Focused on repository maintenance and providing code review feedback this month. They merged a pull request to remove the Codecov configuration from CI in ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry (#1101). In addition to this change, they were highly engaged in collaboration, providing 11 code reviews for their peers. Their work primarily involved modifications to configuration files.

nonsense: Focused on improving CI and testing infrastructure, opening a significant pull request in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17314) to add nightly sync tests. This work involved substantial changes, modifying 62 files with over 1100 new lines of code. In addition to this development effort, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. Their contributions were concentrated on test and configuration files, reflecting a focus on bugfixes and testing.

joshklop: Contributed directly to the codebase this month through 3 commits. These changes modified 42 files, adding over 1,200 lines of code. This activity was categorized as 'other work' and was not associated with any pull requests or issues.

serpixel: Focused on improving the acceptance test suite for `ethereum-optimism/optimism` this month. Their main contribution involved porting tests, which resulted in a significant refactor in PR #17300 that removed nearly 500 lines of code. To support this effort, they also opened and closed two related tracking issues in `ethereum-optimism/infra` (#444, #440). All of serpixel's code changes were concentrated on enhancing the project's test files.

ajsutton: This month, ajsutton focused on CI configuration, merging a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17296) to adjust how a CI job runs. In addition to this change, they were an active collaborator, providing 3 code reviews and leaving 12 comments across various issues and pull requests. Their work this period centered on modifications to configuration files.

Wazabie: This month, Wazabie focused on upgrading several Sepolia environments in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository. They submitted three open pull requests (#1182, #1181, #1180) to advance the Mode, Metal, and Zora chains, which included changes across 37 files (+605/-26 lines). Wazabie also contributed one review approval, and their code changes were primarily focused on documentation and other operational updates.
